DataElement.preferredName: Excisional Biopsy Colorectal Pathology Surgical Procedure SpecimenProcedure
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.:Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.:The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination._Surgical Procedure is a diagnostic or treatment medical procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue._The procedure used to obtain a sample fpr pathological studies

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Excisional Biopsy Colorectal Pathology Surgical Procedure
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.:Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.:The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination._Surgical Procedure is a diagnostic or treatment medical procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.:Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.:The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.
Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.

The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.

Property.preferredDefinition: Surgical Procedure is a diagnostic or treatment medical procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 9/28/10 Released for use in caTissue Suite version 1.1 and/or 1.2 per owners direction.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The procedure used to obtain a sample fpr pathological studies

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated system generated definition with current NCIt definition. mc 11/12/12

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Polypectomy; surgical removal of a polyp.

Concepts.definition: Complete or partial removal of a polypoid lesion from the mucosal surface.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal of fluid or a sample of fluid and cells through a needle. (from medicinenet.com)

Concepts.definition: Procedure using suction, usually with a thin needle and syringe, to remove bodily fluid or tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery for breast cancer in which the breast, most or all of the lymph nodes under the arm, and the lining over the chest muscles are removed. Sometimes the surgeon also removes part of the chest wall muscles.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of one or both breasts, including the areola, nipple, and the majority of the axillary lymph nodes, but sparing the pectoralis major muscle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the breast.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the breast.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal and examination of the sentinel node, the lymph node which is first in receiving the lymphatic drainage of a specified anatomic location and is most likely to be affected by the lymphatic spread of cancer.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal and examination of the sentinel node, the lymph node which is first in receiving the lymphatic drainage of a specified anatomic location and is most likely to be affected by the lymphatic spread of cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery for rectal cancer that spares the anus and leaves the sphincter intact. Surgery is performed through the anus and removes only the rectal tumor and small amounts of surrounding tissue.

Concepts.definition: Surgery for rectal cancer that spares the anus and leaves the sphincter intact. Surgery is performed through the anus and removes only the rectal tumor and small amounts of surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (lo-BEK-toe-mee) The removal of a lobe.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of a lobe of an organ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical procedure to remove tissue from the prostate using an instrument inserted through the urethra.

Concepts.definition: Prostate tissue removal via a cystoscope.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove the entire prostate. The two types of radical prostatectomy are retropubic prostatectomy and perineal prostatectomy.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of all of the prostate as well as some surrounding tissue, including lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal of tissue from the prostate for microscopic examination, using a needle.

Concepts.definition: Removal of tissue from the prostate for microscopic examination, using a needle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (noo-mo-NEK-toe-mee) An operation to remove an entire lung.

Concepts.definition: The excision of part or all of a lung.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

Concepts.definition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a needle for examination under a microscope. Also called fine-needle aspiration.

Concepts.definition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal of a wedge-shaped portion of tissue, for microscopic examinaton.

Concepts.definition: Removal of a wedge-shaped portion of tissue, for microscopic examinaton.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal of a wedge-shaped portion of tissue, for microscopic examinaton.

Concepts.definition: Removal of a wedge-shaped portion of tissue, for microscopic examinaton.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal of the breast, pectoral muscles, axillary lymph nodes, and associated skin and subcutaneous tissue (from MeSH).

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of one or both breasts, including the areola, nipple, axillary lymph nodes, and pectoral muscles.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The surgical removal of a portion of a kidney.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a portion of a kidney.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No Value Exists

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of a triangular wedge shaped section of tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Whipple Resection - Pancreaticoduodenectomy - Total Pancreatectomy
Whipple Resection - Pancreaticoduodenectomy - Partial Pancreatectomy
Trephine Biopsy
Removal of tissue through the bronchial wall, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: Removal of tissue through the bronchial wall, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete.: A specialty in which manual or operative procedures are used in the treatment of disease, injuries, or deformities.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.
The branch of medical science that treats disease or injury by operative procedures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Major Airway Resection
Mediastinoscopic Biopsy
A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Tail of the Pancreas Partial Pancreatectomy

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Tail of the Pancreas Partial Pancreatectomy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The left extremity of the pancreas within the lienorenal ligament.: Surgical removal of part of the pancreas.

Concepts.definition: The left extremity of the pancreas within the lienorenal ligament.
Surgical removal of part of the pancreas.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Body of the Pancreas Partial Pancreatectomy

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Body of the Pancreas Partial Pancreatectomy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The part of the pancreas from the point where it crosses the portal vein to the point where it enters the lienorenal ligament.: Surgical removal of part of the pancreas.

Concepts.definition: The part of the pancreas from the point where it crosses the portal vein to the point where it enters the lienorenal ligament.
Surgical removal of part of the pancreas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Very large in expanse or scope; having great extent from one side to the other.: Removal or excision by surgical measures.

Concepts.definition: Very large in expanse or scope; having great extent from one side to the other.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not otherwise specified.: Removal or excision by surgical measures.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A closed plane curve resulting from the intersection of a circular cone and a plane cutting completely through it, especially a plane not parallel to the base.: Removal or excision by surgical measures.

Concepts.definition: A closed plane curve resulting from the intersection of a circular cone and a plane cutting completely through it, especially a plane not parallel to the base.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Computed Tomography Image Guided Biopsy Needle Biopsy

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Computed Tomography Image Guided Biopsy Needle Biopsy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis. : The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis, using imaging technology.: The removal of tissue or fluid with a needle for examination under a microscope. Also called fine-needle aspiration.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis, using imaging technology.
The removal of a tissue sample using a needle, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.: Blocks; refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.

Concepts.definition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.
Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Both Aspirate and Biopsy

Lymphadenectomy - regopnal nodes
Fiberoptic Bronchoscopic Biopsy
Suprapubic or Retropubic Enucleation
Subtotal or Partial Resection

combine the         Surgical procedure in which  tissue is obtained using either computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The procedure is done in awake (usually sedated) patients or under general anesthesia. For either computed tomography or MRI, the lesion is imaged in reference to a frame attached to the skull, from which stereotactic coordinates are computed for selected target points.  The technique combines the advantages of FNA (no scar, no anesthesia, inexpensive), excisional biopsy (acquisition of solid pieces of tissue rather than smears) and needle localization (precise guidance by x-ray or ultrasound imaging).
Resection of a segment of an organ or partial resection of a gland.

Concepts.definition: Resection of a segment of an organ or partial resection of a gland.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A particular course of action intended to achieve a result.

Concepts.definition: An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.
